Dear Ms. Johnson:
Attached is the Special Investigation Report for the above referenced facility. Due to the
violations identified in the report, a corrective action plan is required. The corrective action
plan is due 15 days from the date of this letter, must be completed and routed in CWLM,
and must include the following:
• How compliance with each rule will be achieved.
• For any repeat violations, why the prior corrective action plan did not result
in compliance.
• Who is directly responsible for implementing the corrective action for each
violation.
• Specific time frames for each violation as to when the action steps will be
completed or implemented.
• How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
• The signature of the responsible party and a date.
If you desire technical assistance in addressing these issues, please feel free to contact
me. In any event, the corrective action plan is due within 15 days. Failure to submit an
acceptable corrective action plan will result in disciplinary action.
Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any
questions. In the event that I am not available, and you need to speak to someone
immediately, please contact the area manager, Jessica VandenHeuvel at 616-204-6992.
P.O. BOX 30650 • LANSING, MICHIGAN 48909
www.michigan.gov • (517) 335-1980

Sincerely,
Lonia Perry Calloway, Licensing Consultant

III. INVESTIGATION
Rule Code & CPA Rule 400.12206 Staff qualifications: volunteer,
Section contractors on central registry.
Description (2)A staff member must be of responsible character and suitable
and able to meet the needs of children and families served by the
agency.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation.
Type
Allegation The agency's licensing worker used inappropriate and derogatory
language when talking about the foster parent. This worker's
behavior was very unprofessional and disrespectful toward the
foster parent.
Investigation Interviews:
On 2/21/2025 I spoke with Complainant about the allegations by
telephone. Complainants confirmed the information as reported by
Foster Parent A.
On 2/21/2025 I interviewed Foster Parent A by telephone. Foster
Parent A confirmed the allegations in the complaint. Foster
Parent A reported on 2/14/2025 her licensing worker, Licensing
Worker (LW) 1’s work phone accidentally called them while LW 1
and LW 2, were talking on another phone. Foster Parent A
reported LW 2 is the worker who completed a recent special
evaluation against their foster home; and the first thing they heard
during the call between the two workers was LW 2 talking
disparaging, disrespectfully, and unprofessionally about them as a
foster parent. LW 2 was heard calling her “Bitch” numerous times.
Such as “that bitch lets those children do whatever the fuck they
want”; that’s why one foster child wants to go back to “that bitches
house because she can do whatever she wants”. Foster Parent A
reported the conversation between LW 1 and LW 2 went on for
two-minutes until LW 1 hung up the phone. Foster Parent A said
LW 1 called them back reporting that LW 1’s phone had
accidentally called them. LW 1 asked how much they heard and
Foster Parent A responded enough to know that they want to have
their case (the special evaluation) dismissed. Foster Parent A said
they told LW 1 they heard LW 2 call them all kind or “bitches”. LW
1 tried to explain that was just how they, as younger females,
speak when talking about other females.
2

Foster Parent A reported a concern that LW 2 is bias against them
and that the behavior demonstrated by LW 2 proves that. Foster
Parent A reported believing the attitude she described above for
LW 2(not the language) was on display when LW 2 was
conducting the recent special evaluation against their foster home.
A special evaluation that resulted in the foster children’s
replacement from Foster Parent A’s foster home and a
recommendation by the agency for revocation of their license.
Foster Parent A stated they felt LW 2 was hostile in her tone at the
first foster home visit, and they did not believe what LW 2
assessed or observed during LW 2’s visit to their foster home.
During a meeting LW 2 reported the foster children did not love
them, disagreed with statements made by them. Foster Parent A
did not provide any other specific behavior by LW 2 to explain why
they thought there was proof that LW 2 was bias against them.
Foster Parent A admitted to speaking with an agency supervisor
about her concern with LW 2 Foster Parent A said they called
Licensing Supervisor 1 (LS 1) and left a message, but LS 1 did not
call them back until after Licensing Supervisor 2 (LS 2) received
the email of the complaint that was sent to Lansing. Foster Parent
A said prior to this incident they had a meeting with LS 1, LW 1
and LW 2 about their special evaluation and the proposed
recommendation for their foster home license.
I had communication with Chief Administrator (CA) about the
allegations by email on 2/20/2025 and 3/5/2025. Chief
Administrator indicated this incident was brought to her attention
the day it occurred. She indicated Licensing Supervisor 1
reported it to Section Manager who alerted her. CA reported they
met with their labor relations representative, reassigned the case
to someone else, and LS 1 made attempts to remedy the
situation. CA reported the agency was also alerted of this incident
through Division of Child Welfare Licensing (DCWL) Director after
a complaint was received from the DCWL team.
On 3/5/2025 I interviewed LS 1 and LW 1 via TEAMS separately. I
interviewed LW 2 via TEAM on 3/6/2025. All three staff persons
reported the allegation of LW 2 using derogatory language, the
word “Bitch” in discussing and referencing Foster Parent A was
true. The staff persons reported on how this incident came to be.
LS 1 reported she is the supervisor for the agency’s special
evaluation unit; and this is why she was involved related to this
incident. She reported LW 1 is Foster Parent A’s ongoing
3

Licensing worker and LW 2 is the worker completing a special
evaluation pertaining to Foster Parent A’s foster home. LS 1 said
LW 1 and LW 2 contacted her separately after the incident
occurred to give her a heads up about what had happened. Both
LW 1 and LW 2 told her that LW 2 was venting to LW 1 by way of
their personal cells about incidents that happened related to the
special evaluation. Foster Parent A had contacted LW 2 and was
denying all that was assessed to be going on related to the special
evaluation. LW 2 called LW 1 and was expressing her
frustrations, when LW 1 other phone accidentally called Foster
Parent A and Foster Parent A heard a portion of the telephone
conversation between LW 1 and L W 2. LS 1 said LW 2 did not
say specifically why she was so frustrated, but LS 1 stated that
Foster Parent A has a tendency to repeatedly phone and email
staff several times a day, and that behavior can be frustrating. LS
1 reported LW 2 told her repetitive contacting behavior had
occurred by Foster Parent A the day of this telephone incident.
LS 1 said LW 1 and LW 2 both admitted LW 2 used negative
language in talking about Foster Parent A, and used the “B” word
in referencing Foster Parent A.
LS 1 reported Foster Parent A contacted her about the workers’
telephone incident, and she listened to Foster Parent A. She let
Foster Parent A voice her concern; and advised Foster Parent A
that she would follow up on the matter; and she did. She said LW
2 and LW 1 were given disciplinary actions related to using their
personal phone and discussing agency business. She reported,
LW 1 action was more a discussion and LW 2 received a formal
verbal counseling by way of a Memo of Expectation. LS 1
reported neither worker had received prior disciplinary actions.
LS 1 reported Foster Parent A’s special evaluation and what
transpired between LW 1 and LW 2 during the telephone call were
separate matters. There was no need to transfer the case related
to that; as the special evaluation had been completed. The
agency met with Foster Parent A related to the special evaluation,
and the agency’s recommendation for revocation.
LW 1 confirmed information as indicated by LS 1. LW 1 added
that she and LW 2 were not at the agency at the time of their
telephone conversation. LW 2 called her, and they were on their
personal cell phones. She said LW 2 contacted her because
Foster Parent A had been calling and texting long conversations
to she and LW 2, due to the agency’s recommendation about the
special evaluation. She said LW 2 was voicing her frustration
about that, and LW 2’s disappointments about the case. LW 1
4

was unsure how her work phone somehow dialed Foster Parent
A. She reported realizing it had about two minutes into their
conversation, so she advised LW 2 she would hang up and call
Foster Parent A. During her call to Foster Parent A, she inquired
of Foster Parent A what had Foster Parent A heard and Foster
Parent A said she heard LW 2 called her the “B” word, meaning
bitch, and that it was unprofessional. Foster Parent A asked her
whether LW 1 felt such was unprofessional and LW 1 said she
agreed it was adverse. LW 1 tried to explain to Foster Parent A,
that sometimes when women talk, they use the “B” word in talking.
She also admitted in other scenarios their use of the “B” word has
usually been within a friendship content, and since Foster Parent
A is a client/customer it was unprofessional. LW 1 reported this
was her first time hearing LW 2 to use the “B” word language to
refer to a foster parent. LW 1 repeated, LW 2 was upset related
Foster Parent A’s behavior, and what had occurred related to the
children in the foster home; and LW 2 was frustrated and just
venting that frustration.
LW 1 reported since Foster Parent A asked for LW 2’s supervisor,
she texted LS 1 to apprise LS 1 of what had occurred. An
informal meeting was held with her by LS 1 and Section Manager
related to the incident and her involvement in it.
LW 2 confirmed information as reported by LS 1 and LW 1 related
to the telephone call between she and LW 1; what transpired
during the call; how the telephone came to be; her using LW 1 as
a sounding board to vent her frustration about Foster Parent A’s
behavior, and the special evaluation, and the consequence for her
due to language she used toward Foster Parent A during the call.
LW 2 denied any bias or negative feelings toward Foster Parent A
impacting her actions on any special evaluation.
On 3/5/2025 I interviewed LS 2 via TEAMS. I Interviewed LS 3 via
TEAMS on 3/6/2024.
Licensing Supervisor 2 (LS 2) is LW 1’s immediate supervisor
and Licensing Supervisor 3 (LS 3) is LW 2’s immediate
supervisor. Neither LS 2 nor LS 3 had direct knowledge of the
allegations. Both had been informed of the incident and resulting
disciplinary action for LW 2 by the Section Manager. Neither LS
2 or LS 3 reported LW 1 or LW 2 having any prior disciplinary
actions or concerns related to their interaction and treatment to
foster parents or caregivers.
5

Documentation Reviewed:
• Memorandum dated 2/21/2025 from LS 1 to LW 2
indicating a formal verbal warning. That moving forward LW
2 will adhere to following professional standards by:
Respectful Conduct, treating all clients and colleagues with
professionalism whether they are present or not; Discretion
in Conversations, by being mindful of where and how she
engages in conversations, ensuring all conversations
remain private; Company Representation by remembering
her behavior reflects MDHHS and must align with
MDHSS’s values, professionalism, respect and integrity.
Analysis Based on interviews and document review, the evidence showed
LW 2 used derogatory words, and unprofessional language when
conversing with a coworker about a foster parent, and the foster
parent’s behavior/case during normal work hours. The workers’
telephone conversation was inadvertently overheard by Foster
Parent A. In this instance the worker did not demonstrate the
responsible character suitable to meet the needs of children and
families served by the agency.
Conclusion Violation Established
IV. RECOMMENDATION
Based on investigative findings the facility is not in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules. Upon receipt of an acceptable corrective action plan, it
is recommended that the current license status be continued.
